Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Story: It was nearly midnight when my phone buzzed. I saw my friend’s name flash on the screen, and when I answered, I could hear her sobbing. She could barely get the words out—her family had just gotten terrible news, and she needed someone to talk to. I sat up in bed, heart pounding, trying to listen and comfort her, knowing how much she relied on me in moments like this. But as I glanced at the clock, I remembered that tomorrow was Sunday—my stepmom always expected our weekly call in the morning. She’d been clear about how much those calls meant to her, especially since I’d moved out. I could already hear her voice, gentle but disappointed, if I sounded tired or distracted. My friend’s pain pulled at me, but so did the weight of my stepmom’s expectations. I felt torn, caught between being the supportive friend I wanted to be and the caring step-child I was supposed to be. The pressure built inside me as I tried to figure out how I could possibly be both at once.
